metadata.title: Homogeneous multimetallic catalysts: Part 9. Hydroformylation of norbornene by cobalt-ruthenium bimetallic catalyst

accepted June 20,1989) Recently homogeneous multimetallic catalysts have been attracting much interest, since they are expected to show unique catalytic activities and selectivities which cannot be achieved by a single metal catalyst [1-3]. We have been interested in the characteristic catalysis and cluster chemistry of cobalt-ruthenium bimetallic systems [4-6]. In the course of our re- search work on carbonylation reactions by these systems, we have recently found that the cobalt-catalyzed hydroformylation of olefins is remarkably accelerated by addition of Ru3(CO)i2, which has essentially no catalytic hydroformylation activity by itself [7]. From the point of view of eluci- dating the cobalt-ruthenium bimetallic synergistic effect, stoichiometric reactions of acylcobalt complexes with various metal hydrides seem to be informative. In fact, it has been revealed that the dinuclear reductive elimina- tion of an aldehyde from an acylcobalt complex and HRu(CO)4~ is much faster than that with HCo(CO)4 [8, 9]. This fact suggests that also in the catalytic hydroformylation by the cobalt-ruthenium bimetallic catalyst, a ruthenium hydride species participates in the step of hydrogenolysis of an acylcobalt intermediate. However, these stoichiometric reactions were conducted under ambient conditions, and no direct information was ob- tained on the reaction under catalytic hydroformylation conditions (at ca. 100 C and under high CO and H; pressures). In order to obtain further information on the mechanism of the cobalt-ruthenium bimetallic syn- ergistic effect, hydroformylation of norbomene by a cobalt-ruthenium mixed catalyst was examined. Norbomene is known to insert easily into an acyl-metal bond [10,11], and therefore in the hydroformylation of norbomene, competition between the hydrogenolysis and norbomene * For Part 8, see [6]. **Author to whom correspondence should be addressed. 0304-5102/89/$3.50 Elsevier Sequoia/Printed in The Netherlands L14 insertion of an acyi complex intermediate may be expected. Here we wish to briefly describe some of the results. A typical procedure for hydroformylation is as follows: a 100 ml autoclave was charged with norbomene (1.88 g, 20 mmol), Co2(CO)g (0.034 g, 0.1 mmol), Ru3(CO)i2 (0-0.43 g, 0-0.66 mmol), and benzene as a solvent (20 ml) under a nitrogen atmosphere, and CO (40 kg cm"2) and Hz (40 kg cm"2) were introduced. The reactor was rapidly heated (within 20 min) to 90 C and the reaction was allowed to proceed at that temperature for 4 h with agitation. After the reaction, the autoclave was rapidly cooled to room temperature and the pressure was released. Then the reaction mixture was quickly treated with an excess of NaBH4, since it proved suitable to determine 2-norbomanecarbaldehyde (1), the hydro- formylation product, as 2-norbomanemethanol (2) due to the instability of (1). After NaBH4 reduction, the reaction products were analyzed by GC, isolated by silica gel column chromatography, and identified by IR, ^ NMR and MS spectra. Results obtained are listed in Table 1. Products detected by GC after NaBH4 reduction were (2) and lactones (3) and (4) (Scheme 1). (4) was confirmed to be a secondary product by the NaBH4 reduction of (3). In the hydroformylation by Co2(CO)g alone, yield of aldehyde (1) was low, and lactone (3) was the major product. In contrast, addition of Ru a(CO) 13, which is essentially catalytically inactive in the hydroformylation of nor- bomene, remarkably promoted the yield of (2), causing it to be the major product, while the selectivities of (3) and (4) were decreased. At the same time acceleration of the CO/H; uptake was observed, as shown in Fig. 1. The higher Ru/Co ratio resulted in a higher selectivity in the hydroformyla- tion. A similar change in product distribution was also observed when TABLE 1 Hydroformylation of norbomene by Co^CC^s-Ri^CO)!^ Run Catalyst Conv.1' Yield" (%)_________ Selectivity (%)* CO:RU (%) (2)d (3f W (2) (3)^(4) 1 1:0 41 9 19 1 21 49 2" 0:1 3 0.8 tr 0 3 1:1 83 29 21 4 35 30 4 1:5 93 38 12 3 41 16 5 1:10 99 55 15 tr 55 15 "Reaction conditions: see text. ''Norbornene consumed/norbomene charged. "Based on the norbomene charged. Norbomane and high-boiling products (probably co-oligomers of norbomene and CO) were also formed, but not determined. ''GC yield. "Isolated yield. ^ield/norbornene consumed. 'RuatCCOn: 0.2 mmol. L15 Co2(CO)a CO/Hz ^"CHO (1) CHaOH (2) Scheme 1. Pressure drop (kg/cur') Co;Ru = 1:1 Co:Ru ' 1:5 Co:Ru 1:10 3 4 Time (h) Fig. 1. Time-dependence curve of the pressure drop in the hydroformylation of nor- bornene with Co/Ru catalysts. Reaction conditions: see text. PPh3 was added to the reaction system, although PPha favored hydrofor- mylation regardless of the presence of Ru 3(00) 13 and caused a decrease in the rate of the reaction, thus requiring a higher reaction temperature. For example, (2) was obtained in 29% and 51% by the hydroformylation with Co;i(CO)8-PPh3 (Co:P=l:3) and CoatCCOs-R^COha-PPha (Co:Ru:P = 1:1:3), respectively, at 110 C for 20 h. The major path of the hydroformylation of an olefin by Co2(CO)g is considered to include alkylcobalt formation by olefin insertion into a cobalt hydride (or by the caged geminate radical pair process [13 -16]), acylcobalt formation by CO insertion, and hydrogenolysis of the inter- mediary acylcobalt forming an aldehyde [12]. In contrast, carbonylation of norbomene is reported to give lactone (3) by a facile insertion of norbomene into an acyl-metal bond and subsequent CO insertion and LI 6 cyclization. Therefore in the cobalt-catalyzed hydroformylation of nor- bomene, addition of H; and insertion of norbornene to the 2-norbomyl- carbonylcobalt complex compete, and this probably decreases the selec- tivity of aldehyde formation. This is also supported by the fact that in- corporation of the sterically bulky PPh3 ligand favored the hydroformylation in comparison to the formation of (3) due to retardation of norbornene insertion. In the hydroformylation of cyclohexene by the Co2(CO)8-Ru3(CO)i2 catalyst, no mixed metal cluster formation was observed by IR [5]. Al- though participation of a trace amount of mixed metal clusters cannot be excluded at this stage, the cluster catalysis seems to be of small importance. Therefore the result that addition of Ru3(CO)i2, which has essentially no carbonylation activity, increased the selectivity of hydroformylation in- dicates that ruthenium favors the hydrogenolysis of the acylcobalt; this is reasonably explained by considering a ruthenium hydride species as a hydrogenolysis reagent of the acylcobalt, as depicted in Scheme 2. That is, Scheme 2. a ruthenium hydride species generated from Ru 3(00) 12, which smoothly causes dinuclear reductive elimination with an acylcobalt, promotes the formation of aldehyde (1) from 2-norbomylcarbonylcobalt complex (5). As a result, the rate of hydrogenolysis of (5) was increased to give (1) as the major product in comparison to the norbornene insertion. If the rate-determining step of the present carbonylation is the hy- drogenolysis of (5), the mechanism stated above also explains the rate enhancement by the addition of Ru3(CO)i2. However, the rate-determining step in the hydroformylation of an internal olefin is reported to be initial interaction between the olefin and HCo(CO)4 [17,18], and if the alkyl- cobalt formation from norbornene and HCo(CO)4 is the slow step, the rate enhancement is not explicable by the ruthenium hydride-promoted aldehyde formation. In such a case, ruthenium should also be involved in the initial activation of norbornene, and to make these points clear, further study including kinetic measurements is needed. L17 In conclusion, by using norbomene as an olefin, it was revealed that in the hydroformylation by the cobalt-ruthenium mixed metal catalyst, ruthenium participates, at least in the hydrogenolysis step of the acylcobalt, to affect the product distribution. Further investigation on the mechanism of the cobalt-ruthenium synergistic effect is now in progress. References 1 P. Braunstein and J. Rose, in I.
